questions.text: What is the likely reason for a patient showing both unilateral and bilateral abducent palsy?
questions.explanation:
Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI)

Type

Motor

Origin

Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla).

Course

Functional component
  • General somatic efferent fibres: Arise from the abducent nucleus in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball.
  • General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Supply

Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball

Clinical aspect

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to abducens nerve palsy
  • Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to:
    • Inability to abduct the eye
    • Diplopia (double vision)
    • Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus)

What is the probable diagnosis for a man of 45 years who arrives at the emergency department with an abrupt loss of vision and experiencing painful movements of the eye? Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is observed in the affected eye. Further visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma in the same eye.
questions.explanation:
Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis (Option D)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features
  • Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.
  • A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).
  • Optic atrophy present

Clinical features
  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Uhthoff's symptom: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, occurs in patients with isolated optic neuritis.
  • Pulfrich's phenomenon: Depth perception may be impaired, particularly for the moving object.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

Management of Optic neuritis:

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man with diabetes, who has reported a decline in vision and whose fluorescein angiography displays the depicted image?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR:

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR: (Option A)

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR: (Option B)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

 

Severe NPDR: (Option C)

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months

 

Very severe NPDR:

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): (Option D)

Mild-moderate PDR:

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR:

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

It is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion.
questions.explanation:
Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the Lateral Geniculate body (LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex
  • The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

questions.text: Where is the location of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.explanation:
Reaction

Description

Causes

Amaurotic light reflex

 

Absence of direct light reflex on the affected side and an absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side.

Optic and retinal lesions on the affected side

Efferent pathway defect

Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. Near reflex is also absent on the affected side.
  • Parasympatholytic drugs (e.g. atropine, homatropine)
  • Internal ophthalmoplegia
  • Third-nerve paralysis.

Marcus Gunn pupil or RAPD

 
  • The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception.
  • It is the first sign of optic nerve disorder.
  • Tested by a swinging flashlight test.

Incomplete optic nerve lesions (Optic neuritis) (Option A) and severe retinal diseases (Retinopathy, CRVO)

Adie’s Pupil

 
  • Reaction to light is absent, and the near reflex is very slow and tonic.
  • It is usually unilateral, associated with absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women.
  • It shows pupillary constriction to 0.125% Pilocarpine due to denervation supersensitivity.

Postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP)

 

Reaction to near reflex is present, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e. there is light near dissociation.

Neurosyphilis

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil

Light reflex is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side.

Optic tract lesion (Option B)

questions.text: Which tuberculosis drug causes impairment of color vision and optic neuritis?
questions.explanation:
Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis (Option C)
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green colour blindness
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

questions.text: Which nerve defect causes lagophthalmos?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon) (Option A), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

questions.text: Which disease is associated with bilateral optic neuritis and transverse myelitis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Neu

Aspect

Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)

Definition

Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO), also known as Devic's disease, is a rare autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and transverse myelitis.

Etiology

NMO is associated with the presence of autoantibodies called aquaporin-4 (AQP4) antibodies, which target the AQP4 water channel protein found on astrocytes in the central nervous system.

Clinical Features

Optic Neuritis: Inflammation of the optic nerve causing vision loss, pain, and eye movement difficulties.
- Transverse Myelitis: Inflammation of the spinal cord leading to sensory, motor, and autonomic dysfunction.
